docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers reported yesterday that there may be a link between some newer drugs prescribed for schizophrenia and a dangerous inflammation of the pancreas. The study, which looked at patients taking any of four antipsychotic drugs, examined all cases of pancreatitis that were reported to the Food and Drug Administration or written up in medical journals between January 1981 and February 2002. It found that more cases were associated with three newer drugs than with an older generation drug.

headline.main: Pancreatitis Risk Seen In Schizophrenia Drugs

docs.abstract: Dr P Murali Doraiswamy, Duke University division for biological psychiatry chief, authors report in journal Pharmacotherapy that outlines potential link between newer generation schizophrenia drugs and pancreatitis; contends that preliminary data show cause for concern, but holds that more research is needed to determine if increase in inflammation of pancreas is directly related to use of antipsychotics known as atypicals, or if those people with schizophrenia have other risk factors that may explain higher incidence of disease (M)
